title: ryainair worst airline passengers alcohol
story: The budget airline came out worst in a Which  travel survey which found that  per cent of Ryanair passengers had to deal with having a badly behaved passenger on their flight in the last year.And one in ten passengers on UK airlines experienced some kind of obnoxious behaviour in the same period, including drunkenness, verbal abuse and shouting.Thomas Cook was the second worst for disruption , followed by TUIand easyJet .Although airlines have come out in support of plans to clamp down on binge drinking at airports, Which  says they are partly to blame for encouraging drunkenness.The consumer advice firm spoke to cabin crew on low wages who said they were given a commission on the amount of in-flight drinks they sold.And Which  also said one staff member claimed they had been groped by drunk passengers, but reporting disruptive behaviour can take hours of unpaid paperwork.Rory Boland, Which  Travel editor, said: People should be able to take a flight without having to worry about their trip being disrupted or journey erted by rowdy passengers who have had one too many.Airlines need to take more responsibility for preventing passengers having too many drinks, and incentivising cabin staff to flog more gin and tonics isn’t the right way to do that.The survey was carried out on , Which  members.According to the Civil Aviation Authority , there was an average of  disruptive passenger incidents a year on flights between  and .In , the number increased to a whopping .Ryanair has been contacted for comment.

title: new york blue glow explosion power plant sword aliens
story: Spencer Pesce, of Queens, believed hostile UFOs were attacking his home town when the skies above him  suddenly turned an eerie flashing blue.“I ran into my parents’ room and shouted, ‘Get up, it’s happening!’” said the -year-old .“I swear to God, I thought it was aliens.Pesce was watching TV when equipment  feet in the air maled, sending , volts of electricity coursing to the ground and creating a reaction known as an electrical arc flash.“I looked outside and it was as bright as day. It was flashing blue,” Pesce said.“And there was like a humming, like a giant machine starting up, you know, like a giant alien spaceship starting up like what you see in the movies.”Pesce first stashed a weapon within easy reach and ventured outside, where other residents were gathered to take in the awesome sight.“I grabbed a samurai sword and left it by my door, put my boots on and went outside. If it was aliens, I was going to defend my family,” he said.“It was pretty scary,” he told the New York Post. “I was prepared with my samurai sword just in case the aliens were hostile.”Electricity was cut off for thousands while the busy La Guardia airport was shut down by the blast - leaving dozens of flights being grounded.And it wasnt just Pesce who feared aliens were about to strike the Big Apple.Twitter was awash with clips showing the flickering light piercing through low-hanging cloud - with some claiming it was a UFO invasion.But the New York Fire Department soon confirmed it was investigating a transformer explosion at a power facility in the Astoria area of Queens.Jim Long, a spokesman for Fire Department New York, said: There was a boom and a bang and a flash of light.Its all under control but were still getting calls from residents wondering what happened.The blue flashes that briefly lit up the night sky were caused by a power surge and electrical arching and sparked a transformer explosion and a small fire, said power giant Con Edison.The firms spokesman Bob McGee added that there were no injuries.Social media lit up with videos and photos of the bright light in the night sky over New York City.Why is the sky lit up bright blue in Queens New York City right now  Is it fireworks  Louis Santoro, a New York City resident, wrote on Twitter.One resident, Joe Calderone, told the New York Post: Damn, I thought a UFO hit Con Ed.Con Edisons McGee reassured residents after internet speculation that aliens or the villain Thanos from the recent Avengers movie Infinity War had invaded.No, it wasnt space aliens, he said.All power has been restored to normal. But the videos online of the blue lights in the sky are still flying all over the internet, McGee said.The fire caused scattered outages, stalled some city trains and briefly blacked out LaGuardia Airport, which is located in Queens, because of a transmission dip, he said.It also caused some flight cancellations and delays but all power and services were restored before midnight, McGee said.New York City Mayor Bill de Blasio said in a message on Twitter that Con Edison was evaluating the extent of power outages in the area.La Guardia Airport suffered a power blackout and was briefly closed for inspection by aviation officials.But travellers - including thousands of festive tourists - suffered severe delays and cancellations.City Council Speaker Corey Johnson tweeted that La Guardia was “temporarily closed due to a power outage resulting from the Con Edison explosion.”

title: specs cure kids car sickness glasses
story: The £ specs, designed by French car-maker Citroen, look rather unusual - but could save you a lot of stress when taking the kids on long car journeys.Named Seetroen, the glasses take just  minutes to take effect and enable kids to read or watch films in the back of the car without feeling unwell.The strange design features two large circular lenses at the front and one on either side along the legs of the specs.Each of the four lenses contains coloured liquid, which moves with the motion of the body, acting as a horizon.Citroen says million people across Europe suffer from motion sickness.Using the glasses, the brain receives the missing information from the eyes peripheral vision, filling in the gaps and preventing the mixed signals that cause motion sickness - or kinetosis.The middle part of the ear is responsible for balance and detecting acceleration, turning, rising, falling and slowing down.When in a car, plane or boat, our eyes tell the brain were not moving but the ears say we are - this confuses the brain and causes nausea.Reading, or watching a screen while in the car makes this sensation even worse, as the eyes become focused on a stationary object, telling the brain more strongly that the body is not moving.Children and teenagers going through puberty are the most susceptible to motion sickness.The Seetroen glasses are suitable for those aged  and above - as this is the age at which the inner becomes fully developed.As they dont have lenses, the glasses can be shared between people and can even be worn over prescription glasses.After the initial symptoms have settled, the glasses can be removed again, so children wont have to complain about looking silly in them for too long.

title: cops hunting man drag teenage girl car bus

title: minibus carrying 20 passengers overturns on scottish borders

title: highs lows and dance moves of british politics 2018 wooding
story: Here, Sunday Political Editor David Wooding takes a light-hearted look at the year in politics for his annual awards, The Wooders.Chancellor Philip “Spreadsheet” Hammond launched a wave of blue-on-blue insults at Cabinet ­colleagues — especially Brexiteers — when he gleefully talked of “flushing out extremists”.He branded Boris Johnson a “bogeyman” and cuttingly said of Welfare ­Secretary Esther McVey: “The only thing she knows how to do well is a blow dry.”But while both of them have since left the Cabinet, Big Phil is still in place.Donald Trump arrived late for his ­meeting with the Queen during his ­controversial summer visit to Britain.The -year-old monarch was seen ­looking at her watch after being kept standing outside Windsor Castle for  minutes.But the US ­President brashly insisted he was early and, you’ve guessed it, his late arrival was “fake news”.Goes to the protester with the placard: “Super- callous, fragile ego, Trump, you are atrocious.”Ex-PM David Cameron told pals he fancied a political comeback as he is “bored s**tless”. We’re not surprised he’s “s**tless” — he left his colleagues up to their knees in the stuff.Boris Johnson warned that ­trying to sell the PM’s Brexit blueprint to voters was “like ­trying to polish a turd”. Six months on, Theresa May is still buffing away and her tin of Election Pledge is nearly empty.Mrs May was written off  months ago after that disastrous party conference speech — but a year on, she shimmied on stage to Abba’s Dancing Queen.Since then, she’s survived a no-confidence vote forced by Tory rebels and attempts to sink her loathed Brexit plan. Who’d bet against her being in No this time next year Brexiteer-in-chief Jacob Rees-Mogg and his supporters were ­likened to Dad’s Army after their attempted leadership coup flopped. But the posh Tory brushed off the jibe, ­saying: “I’ve always admired Captain Mainwaring.”On a visit to Beijing, Foreign ­Secretary Jeremy Hunt tried telling his opposite number that his we is Chinese — but called her “Japanese”. The two countries are bitter rivals and neither his hosts nor his ­missus were amused.Labour’s Emily Thornberry described the Government as “the equivalent of Reservoir Dogs remade by the Chuckle Brothers”.EU Commission chief Jean-Claude “Drunker” Juncker just about struggled to stay on his feet at summits this year.He ruffled a woman official’s hair and was ­challenged by Mrs May when he dubbed her “nebulous”.But he insisted they ended up kissing. It’s hard to know how he’d remember after his famous lunches.Jeremy Corbyn infuriated MPs — and kept lip-readers busy — when he mouthed “stupid woman” at the PM at Commons ­question time.The ­Labour leader, who says he wants a “kinder, gentler” politics, insisted he didn’t, but lip-readers said he did. Stupid boy.Angry female MPs said “knickers” to Tory MP Christopher Chope after he single-handedly blocked moves to make taking pictures up skirts a criminal offence — and hung a string of undies outside his ­Commons office.Two ­Russian hitmen wanted for the Salisbury nerve agent attack claimed they were sightseers ­visiting the city’s cathedral and insisted they had left early to escape a dusting of snow. Pull the other one, Vlad.Sir Nick Clegg once said he found the “messianic Calornian new-worldy touchy-feely culture of ­Facebook a little grating”.Now he’s happy to take a £million-a-year job as its global affairs boss, and it’s smiley emojis all the way to the bank.Labour deputy leader Tom Watson shed an incredible st after giving up sugar, eating healthier food and exercising.Trim Tom should have a word with his boss about plans to gorge on ­taxpayers’ money.Forgetful Sir Vince Cable was so busy plotting to halt Brexit, he missed a key Commons vote on it, allowing the Customs Bill to scrape through by just three votes.The Lib Dem leader later announced that he will stand down next year. Some of his ten MPs had begun to think he’d already left.Speaker John Bercow was accused of bullying staff, ­muttering “stupid woman” at Commons leader Andrea Leadsom and displaying a “B*****ks To Brexit” car sticker, despite impartiality rules. Yet he’s still in the chair after vowing to “keep buggering on”.Dominic Raab admitted he “hadn’t quite understood” the importance of our £billion-a-year trade with France — four months after becoming Brexit Secretary and a week before he resigned.Tracey Crouch made an unusual stand by resigning over a matter of principle — forcing the Chancellor into a Budget U-turn and saving lives in the process.She quit as Sports Minister over delays to a crackdown on high-stakes betting machines which she blames for suicides among debt-ridden gamblers. Her stand forced the Government to act within days.After Tory Brexiteer John Hayes was knighted — seen as a ploy to buy his ­support for the PM’s hated Brexit plan — colleague Mark Francois urged him to get a coat of arms containing “an utter cock ­rampant on one side and a big chicken on the other”.New Culture Secretary Jeremy Wright revealed he likes to unwind by playing with his “very large” Lego set. Maybe he should be in charge of housing instead.Wannabe PM Boris Johnson milked his exit as Foreign Secretary by inviting a photographer to snap him writing his resignation letter. One MP branded him “a poundshop Churchill impressionist”.It’s not just the wheels of Government that need oiling, but the PM’s joints, judging by her dancing during an ­African trip. Looks like the Maybot needs to add a pair of dancing shoes to her kitten heel collection this year.Pepper the robot was questioned by a  of MPs about the impact of articial intelligence. It was hailed as a Commons first, although anyone who’s seen Theresa May or Sajid Javid in action may beg to dfer.Labour bruiser John Prescott became a victim of ­mistaken identity when his picture appeared in The Times, captioned as Clint Eastwood. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: booze free parliament commons curb drinking culture
story: Strict new controls on drinking within the Westminster estate will be rolled out after agreement among senior MPs.The powerful House of Commons Commission will implement “alcohol-free” areas which should be “encouraged and expanded”.There will also be a marked rise in the range of non-alcoholic drinks and lower strength beers for sale.The restrictions follow Commons Speaker John Bercow allegedly demanding a prohibition-style drink ban during the day.The move comes just over a year since the so-called Pestminster scandal that led to the resignation of Defence Secretary Michael Fallon. He stood accused of “lunging” at a female journalist and kissing her on the lips after a boozy lunch.It also follows the Dame Laura Cox report into bullying and harassment culture on the Parliamentary estate.Abuse of staff may have been made worse by the “ready access” to alcohol across bars and restaurants on the premises.In her report, Dame Laura said: “The steps taken so far to restrict access to alcohol during working hours may need to be revisited.”Changes to the availability of alcohol will also include adverts promoting alcohol in bars will be banned.MPs and staff will also be contacted asking them to “refrain” from drinking in their offices after bars on the estate have shut.Labour MP Jess Phillips last night said: “This is a step in the right direction. Parliament is a place of work and not a cruise ship.“However, unless the culture of power and political friendships mattering more than anything, these measures will be window dressing.”A spokesperson for the House of Commons Commission: “The House of Commons Commission has agreed a number of actions to promote responsible alcohol consumption.Our total trade with the zone last year was worth £billion.International Trade Secretary Dr Fox said: “The Scotch whisky industry supports more than , UK jobs.”“These include increasing the range of non-alcoholic drinks and lower strength beers available, training and supporting staff to refuse to serve customers when necessary, expanding and encouraging alcohol-free areas, discouraging Members and staff from drinking in offices after bars are shut, and not running promotional advertisements.“Bullying and harassment have no place in the House of Commons. title: jeremy hunt brexit britain invisible chain
story: The Foreign Secretary will outline how the UK can promote the benefits of free trade and the rule of law.He will make the pitch on Wednesday — three months before Britain leaves the EU.Speaking to an audience in Singapore, he will say we must use our influence as the fth biggest economy in the world, the second biggest military budget in NATO and a permanent member of the UN Security Council.But he will admit: “We are not a superpower and we do not have an empire”.Mr Hunt will say our new role should be to link “the democracies of the world, those countries who share our values and support our belief in free trade, the rule of law and open societies”.He will add: “We have some of the best connections of any country — whether through the Commonwealth, our alliance with the United States and our friendship with neighbours in Europe.”There is also an opportunity to use “immense reserves” of soft power with , international students in the UK, million visits by tourists last year and our media reaching hundreds of millions, he will insist.Mr Hunt will also make a thinly veiled attack on China.The intervention will come after watchdog Freedom House revealed  countries suffered a decline in political rights and liberties last year.The Foreign Secretary will say: “By , for the first time in our letimes, the world’s biggest economy will not be a democracy — or want to become one.”His comments will heighten diplomatic tensions after the UK raised spy concerns about Chinese tech giant Huawei operating here.China hit back by accusing the UK of “deep-rooted pride and prejudice” with the company denying posing a threat.There are plenty of doom-and-gloom merchants plying their trade in the UK at the minute.There’s the Treasury, which seems to think we’re headed for plague and pestilence after we free ourselves from Brussels. Women are finding their voice.And the most important thing is we are getting heard.We are not going to accept mansplaining or being ­spoken down to “stupid woman”.Feminism is the word of the year, with more and more women standing up for themselves and demanding equality, and I predict that process is going to continue in .Now that I think about it, there were other good things about .It was the year we rediscovered hope in football during the World Cup.We did better than we thought we would — and it’s not often we can say that.The England team and manager Gareth Southgate restored our ­national self-esteem and gave us something to cheer about when there really was not much .The World Cup showed us nice guys can win.Sure, we didn’t bring home the trophy but it’s fair to say Gareth Southgate’s a winner in everyone’s eyes.And it’s not over yet:  is the women’s football World Cup — so that’s something to look forward to with hope.Hope is an important word. title: voice mirror javid must beef
story: NewsopinionVoice of the Mirror: Javid must beef up immigration security before a tragedyThe Home Secretary needs to break criminal gangs exploiting vulnerable people - their lives are at stakeShareByVoice of the Mirror:,  DEC NewsopinionHome Secretary Sajid Javid cut short his holiday to deal with the current refugee crisis "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAfter days of dithering, Sajid Javid has finally woken up to the fact that the refugee crisis is a “major incident”. What gave it away, Home Secretary  Was it the  desperate people who tried to cross the Channel on Christmas Day  The nine on Boxing Day  The eight spotted on a raft by the MS Spirit of Britain ferry  Whatever it was, it took long enough. The question is, “What happens now ” Mr Javid is cutting short his holiday. And it looks like he’s finally taking action, appointing a gold commander and talking about patrols being stepped up. These moves are necessary and to be welcomed. But he must also tackle the causes. Migration is a fact of le. There are lots of reasons people flee their homelands. Syria, for example, is a warzone and many Syrians have lost everything. In desperation, thousands have headed for Europe. And, because gangs are exploiting their panic and fear, one of the most dangerous parts of the journey is near the end. Organised criminals offer them a leline, but at an unbelievable cost: cut-price deals to allow migrants to put their children on boats.   This is not just a couple of conmen chancing their arms. These are cold, hard criminals who don’t caretheir “customers” live or die. One former coastguard officer says it is just a matter of time before there is a tragedy, and rescuers will soon be retrieving bodies rather than saving people. Mr Javid must act before that happens. That means beefing up our patrols and security. And it means smashing the evil networks exploiting vulnerable of people who are doing what we would all dowe lost shyeverything – trying to find a place of safety. Give nurses a lt In the past year, four in  hospitals have put up the cost of parking for visitors, patients and staff. It beggars belief that people going to see sick loved ones face these shyextortionate costs. And it is shocking that NHS staff are being forced to pay to park at work as well. Now, though, a hospital in Essex is trying to tackle the problem by offering nurses free use of a park-and-ride scheme for three months. We welcome this step, which takes some pressure off these most dedicated and selfless people. We hope more health trusts will follow Colchester General’s example – preferably permanently – giving over-worked and underpaid nurses one less thing to worry about. See you in ! Well, there goes . It’s been a funny old year, what with all the political turmoil. On the other hand we had royal weddings and a long, hot summer. England’s footballers even won a World Cup penalty shoot-out. So Happy New Year to all our readers – bring on .

title: armed gangs charging 5000 head
story: NewsArmed gangs charging £, a head to smuggle desperate migrant families to UKEXCLUSIVE: Families are being herded on to inflatables for the perilous -mile journey from Calais to the Kent coastShareCommentsByPatrick Hill:,  DEC NewsAhmad Lorpur has been living in a tent in Calais with his we and two children for four months "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailArmed gangs are smuggling shychildren into Britain on flimsy boats for pound,-a-head, a Sunday Mirror investigation reveals. The kids and their parents – who pay pound, each – are herded on to inflatables and small vessels for the perilous -mile sailing from Calais to the Kent coast. Iraqi Kurdish gangsters use secret social media pages and passwords to drum up business. Then, “like travel agents”, they target refugees in ramshackle camps offering the “special half-price deals” for children. One refugee told us: “You have to pay mafia here to get on a boat to England.” But once in the UK many are picked up by “Mr Bigs” and forced into slavery. Last night Save the Children called our findings “sickening” and echoed a warning by French police that children’s lives are being put at risk. Home Secretary Sajid Javid cut short his holiday to deal with the migrant crisis, which he called a “major incident”. And Immigration Minister Caroline Nokes yesterday held an emergency meeting with the Border Force, Immigration Enforcement and the National Crime Agency in Dover. Our probe came as the toll of migrants plucked from the Channel by British authorities since Christmas Day reached . Many are professionals, business owners or from middle-class backgrounds in Iran, Iraq and Afghanistan. They pay for the crossings after saving up, selling property or borrowing cash. Iranian Ahmad Lorpur, , has been living in a tent in Calais with his we and two children for four months while waiting for his chance to get to the UK. He told us: “You have to pay mafia to get on a boat. They are Iraqi-Kurds. “They call themselves ‘agents’, like travel agents. I have met one of them – a young Iraqi Kurd aged in his s. “He said he lives in England and that I needed to pay pound, each for me and my we to travel there. He said my children can go for half the price – pound,.” Standing with his kids Mariam, seven, and Benyamin, two, Ahmad added: “I have no money left now. It is all gone, butI had pound, I would pay it. “I paid ,to smugglers to get my family out of Iran and into Europe as we suffered persecution for being Christian. We managed to get here four months ago, but now we’re stuck. “It is no good for us here in Calais. My son is sick and we need help. “Everyone is waiting to get on boats to England. It is a big problem.”   An Iraqi-Kurdish refugee who is living at a camp  miles away, near Dunkirk, said desperate refugees contact smugglers through secret Facebook groups.The -year-old man, who lived in the north of England before being deported three years ago, asked not to be named for fear of reprisals. He said: “The names of the Facebook groups regularly change and it is not obvious what they are unless you know about them.“But after you’ve private messaged them, and they’re satisfied you’re not police, they send an agent to meet you in person. It’s still very cloak and dagger.“Once they’re completely happy, they negotiate a deal and give you a number to contact them on a messaging app like Telegram so it’s secure – as well as details of a bank account number for you or a family member to pay the money to. “I cannot risk giving you the details of the Facebook group becausethey found out I would be in a lot of danger. “They have knives and guns. I’m worried they could be watching now.” French officials say the number of detected illegal Channel crossings was  in  but has soared  per cent this year. But in Calais those determined to reach the UK are undeterred. While hundreds are putting their lives at risk on boats, others are paying pound, to stow away on lorries.  In the latest sea incidents, an inflatable containing four migrants was rescued off the Kent coast at around am on Friday.Six hours later another small boat was intercepted with eight people on board.That came after nine people, including three children, were intercepted on a beach in Sandgate, Kent, on Thursday.And more than  migrants were rescued from the Channel on Christmas Day.   Ingrid Parrot, of the French Maritime Police, said extra patrol vessels had been deployed to avert a tragedy. She added: “The figures are unprecedented and very disturbing. The risk is great.“There are  ships and  ferries crossing here every day. What’s more, the currents are strong and the winds almost permanent.” A senior French police source added: “Iraqi Kurds play a major part in the people smuggling rackets.“They are putting lives at risk while profiting from human misery. It is only a matter of time until lives are lost.” Two years ago, UK-based Iraqi Kurd gangster Twana Jamal,  – nicknamed The Godfather – was jailed for five years for a poundmillion-a-year cross-Channel people smuggling racket. And in September, two Albanians and five Brits from Kent were jailed for a total of  years after using small boats and a jet ski to smuggle people into the UK.

title: dry january beckons here expert
story: NewsHere comes Dry January! Expert tips for a painless, tipple-free start to the new yearBrits drank a staggering  units of alcohol a week during the festive season and in January one in ten of us will aiming for a month offShareCommentsByRachel Spencer:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsInformation manager Alison Benson said she changed her le with Dry January"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe statics are quite shyfrightening andyou ever needed a reason to ease up on your booze intake, then now is the time – as Dry January is about to kick in. One in  adults – .million ofus – will have a month off the sauce, according to figures released by Alcohol Change UK. Many will have binged to excess over the festive period, when the average Brit drinks  units of alcohol a week. That’s nearly five times the  units recommended by the NHS. So taking part in Dry January will help you feel both healthier and wealthier. And banishing booze for four weeks can improve your relationship with alcohol in the long term. Dr Richard Piper, from Alcohol Change UK, explains: “Being alcohol-free for  days shows us that we don’t need alcohol to have fun, to relax, to socialise. “For the rest of the year we are better able to make decisions about our drinking and to avoid slipping into drinking more than we really want to.  “Many of us know the risks of alcohol – seven forms of cancer, liver disease, mental health issues – but we are often unaware that drinking less has more immediate benefits too.” Research carried out by the University of Sussex into  Dry January participants found their drinking days on average dropped from . to . per week, the units on each drinking day fell by nearly  per cent, and episodes of drunkenness went from . a month to .. Four out of five felt more in control of their drinking,  per cent saved money,  per cent slept better and realised theydidn’t need drink to have fun,while  per cent had moreenergy. Over half,  per cent, noticed an improvement in their skin and  per cent lost weight. Being booze-free helped in their professional lives too, with  per cent having improved concentration.  Alison Benson, , an information manager from Stoke-on-Trent, Staffs, did Dry January this year and hasn’t touched a tipple since. She said: “I didn’t know when to stop. I found myself in unsafe shysituations and there would be occasions when I’d wake up and didn’t know how I got home – or I’d wake up in strange places. “I found Club Soda, a support group for women who want to stop drinking or moderate theirintake, went to a workshop last November and tried alcohol-free drinks. “On New Year’s Eve I had my last drink and since stopping I’ve felt less anxious, more clear-headed, my sleep has improved – and I still enjoy social situations. I always say I may go back to drinking, but I’m in no hurry to. Dry January changed my le.” Lauren Booker, author of Try Dry, The Official Guide to a Month off Booze, has these tips:  Have a clearout It’s a lot harder to stick to Dry Januaryyou still have bottles of wine and crates of beer in the house. You don’t need to pour it down the drain. Either lock it away in the shed so you’re not tempted or ask a friendyou can leave it at their house until the end of the month.  Treat yourself If you drink a couple of bottles of wine at home and have one night out a week, that’s pound a month on booze. Go on a spa weekend or do something you really love instead. Don’t use the cash for anything mundane. The Dry Jan app shows how much you save.  Find an alternative to your favourite tipple There are alcohol-free wines and beers so find one that tastes as much like your usual drink so you don’t feel you’re missing out. Andyour tipple is a GT try an alcohol-free gin which has all the taste.   Exercise more Exercise releases those feelgood shyendorphins, and you’ll find you’re less sluggish when you kick booze. It’s easier to exercise in the morning without a pounding headache. Andyou can’t hit the gym until later, you’ll have more energy so it won’t feel such a chore.  Buddy up If you can get a friend to join you on Dry January, it will be a lot easier as you can keep each other on trackyou are tempted to have a drink. Try to think of activities you can do together that don’t involve drinking – like going to see a film. If you do go out, decide what you’re going to say when someone asks why you’re not drinking. It will make it easier to stay strong and not think, “Oh, I’ll just have one...”To sign up for Dry January, visit dryjanuary.org.uk or download the Try Dry: The Dry January app via the App Store or Google Play. It lets you track units, calories and money saved by not drinking. Club Soda have a Mindful Drinking Festival in London on January  and . Find out more at joinclubsoda.

title: dying mum writes love letter
story: NewsDying mum writes love letter to daughters to give them guidance once shes goneMum-of-two Lisa was given the heartbreaking news she had terminal cancer last DecemberShareCommentsByNicola Small:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsLisa received the shattering news just weeks after giving birth to her second child "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum who was given less than a year to live just weeks after having her second child has composed a love letter to her daughters to guide them when she’s gone. And the tear-jerking verse has been turned into a book to help children facing similar tragedies. The project is part of the shyextraordinary legacy that Lisa Wells wants to leave her girls Ava-Lily, six, and one-year-old Saffia. Last December bubbly shybeautician Lisa was given the shattering news she had terminal cancer. Since then the inspirational -year-old has made the most of every day – despite having surgery and  rounds of chemotherapy to try to keep the cancer stable.   She said: “Every day I wake up and count my blessings I’m still here. “I never imagined I would live long enough to see my five-week-old baby grow into a -month-old with an amazing little personality. “I’ve seen her take her first steps, I’ve heard her say her first words. All these things I didn’t think I’d be here to see.” Comfort Lisa and husband Dan, , from Frome, Somerset, have not hidden her cancer from their eldest shydaughter, Ava-Lily, but have not told her it is terminal. Lisa said: “She knows there might come a day when I’m not here any more but that’s all we’ve said. “It’s the hardest thing to have to tell your child and it’s why I wanted to write the book. “It is a love letter from my heart with all the sentiments I want to leave my children to help them come to terms with my death. “I cry every time I read it but I’m so, so proud of it.   “I’ve had messages from other mums who bought the book to read with their children and wanted to thank me. “One lady said she’d been given two weeks to live and it was such a huge comfort to her. She has passed away now. “To know I’ve in some way helped another family means such a lot to me.” Lisa wrote the book, called Only one of Me, A love letter from Mum, with the help of shychildren’s author Michelle Robinson. It is being sold to raise money for the cancer counselling charity We Hear You and Mummy’s Star, which supports women and their families affected by cancer shyduring pregnancy. “Be a little bit like Mum,” Lisa writes at the end of her shyheart-rending letter. “Be kind! Be brave! Be free! Remember all our joy and fun when you remember me.” Lisa has kept a moving video diary charting her ups and downs, sharing the vlogs on her Lisa’s Army Facebook page. It has galvanised an army of supporters who have raised pound, for her children’s future. The mum has also been putting together a scrapbook for her daughters with photos and little notes about their precious time together. She said: “One of my biggest fears is that Saffia won’t remember me. So I want her to be able to see for herself who I was. “I’m doing everything I can to leave a trail for my girls. “They will be able to watch the shyvideos and hear my voice and they can read their scrapbooks and see how I wrote.”   Lisa had shown worrying symptoms of bowel cancer while expecting Saffia but her doctor put it down to her pregnancy. It was only after she had Saffia and lost three stone in six weeks that she was sent for a colonoscopy that shyrevealed cancer had spread to her liver and was inoperable. Today Lisa has already outlived her consultant’s prognosis, And she has made the most of the last year – doing things she never shyimagined possible. “I’ve been in a Boyzone video,” she laughed. “Ava and I met Ed Sheeran at one of his concerts. “I’m now a published author, I’ve turned on my town’s Christmas lights, there’s all the fundraising we’ve been doing. “When I’ve not been too sick from chemo I’ve just made the most of every day I’ve had with my family.” Lisa and road surfacer Dan – who have been shytogether since they were  – also ed in August to the stately home where they got married to renew their wedding vows on their tenth anniversary. She said: “I’ve learnt to enjoy every day rather than wasting time thinking that I might not be here much longer.” Lisa’s incredible courage has won her a string of gongs including the Crowdfunder of the Year prize at JustGiving’s annual awards ceremony. “All of this I never shyexpected,” she said. “One thing that shycancer has done to me is made me the person that I always should have been. “If I want to do something, I do it. “This last year has been the worst year of my le but also the best. “I thought  was definitely my last Christmas but here I am a year later and hopefully I will be here to see another one too.”

story: NewsMum moved by council  times in a YEAR tells of traumatic experienceGem Gardner, , from Nottingham, was even forced to stay the night in a McDonalds after a council deemed she had made herself intentionally homelessShareCommentsByJoseph Locker:,  DEC NewsGem Gardner was moved through  dferent hotels with her seven-year-old daughter "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA distressed mum has revealed how she was moved by her local council TEN times within the space of a year.Gem Gardner claims she even stayed in McDonalds for the night as she had nowhere left to go. The -year-old, who has previously suffered from mental health problems, branded the experience of temporary accommodation as traumatic. She claimed Nottingham council even tried to get her to move to Derby - miles from her daughters school. Despite the numerous set-backs, her daughter, Success, had a % attendance record last year. Ms Gardner said: My relationship broke down in London so I had to come back to Nottingham as I had nothing left down there. I could not cope. I ended up with housing aid as I was in rent arrears and I became isolated and depressed.  Research had to be done to seeI had made myself intentionally homeless and I went through three dferent hotels in the six months it took for them to make a decision - which came back that I had despite my relationship breakdowns. I was all alone with my daughter then, and housing aid sent me to Loxley House and said they could help me. At one stage, Gem and her daughter were forced to stay in a hotel that didnt have electricity for three days. She said: When I complained, they threatened to kick me out. Some landlords can be horrible to deal with and take advantage of your situation. The travel costs to get my daughter to school were so expensive as we kept getting put so far away.Ms Gardner eventually got a solicitor and said it is unfortunate there is not enough concern put into where vulnerable women are getting placed. The council has now helped her get a privately rented house in Hyson Green, Nottingham She also has a job after graduating in applied social science and youth work at university, looking after a child on a one-to-one basis at a school.  She added: Im an educated woman. My situation is not who I am. It has opened my eyes to the reality of the system. It seems designed to make people fail. Its not surprising how people fall into prostitution and drugs. But when I was alone in London I thought, I have to do this for my daughter. I am hoping to get a house with my own name on it. My daughter wants to be a clothes designer and shes already wanting to help other people as well. She has written a few cards for homeless people this year. Were in a better position now, but there is always the worry about going back there. Councillor Linda Woodings, portfolio holder for housing and planning at Nottingham City Council, said: This has been a complex case and we’re glad that we’ve ultimately been able to support Ms Gardner back into permanent accommodation.  She was living in a privately-rented property with her child and came to us after her landlord evicted her for non-payment of rent. It took a lot of work to understand what had happened in Ms Gardner’s case and why she had been unable to keep up with the rent. This involved conversations with a number of partner agencies and she was temporarily housed while this took place. The use of bed-and-breakfasts and hotels is clearly not ideal, and the council remains on track to end their use for families by the end of the year. Properties are only used when they have been assessed by our safer housing team as meeting required standards. Where we’ve had concerns, the council has taken appropriate steps to help the owner improve things. Enforcement action is taken where necessary. Unfortunately, there are often restrictions in providing temporary accommodation at city-based hotels over the weekend. We have occasionally been required to move people ahead of the weekend, but always try to get them back into the same hotel so that children’s schooling isn’t disrupted.

title: mums attempt unblock toilet goes
story: NewsMums attempt to unblock toilet goes drastically wrong and sees home evacuatedDominique Heath, from Nailsea, Somerset, used two ordinary household chemicals to unblock her loo but ended up creating a poisonous gas cloudShareCommentsByTristan CorkAmber Hicks:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsDominique Heath has shared her story as a warning "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA mum had to evacuate her home and call emergency services after she created a poisonous gas cloud while attempting to unblock her toilet.Dominique Heath accidentally filled her home with deadly chlorine gas - which was used as a chemical weapon in wars - after using two ordinary household products hours apart. It was when the mum-of-threes throat and eyes started to feel asthey were burning and fumes filled the air that she realised something was very wrong and rang the fire brigade. They ordered her to evacuate her home immediately and cordoned off part of her street in Nailsea, Somerset, reports Bristol Live.  Fire fighters wore breathing apparatuses as they went into the house to ventilate it, and wash away the chemicals to make it safe. Dominique, who wants to warn others of the dangers how easy it is to cause a major chemical incident, had used two bottles of ‘One Shot’ toilet unblocker. Hours later she then poured bleach down the toilet, which she she thinks one of her young children blocked by putting too much toilet paper or a toy down there. “I put the kids to bed at pm, ran a bath, then looked in the toilet and it was still blocked so I thought ‘I’m not getting into the bath like this’, she said. I’ll put my three-litre tub of bleach down there, that should do it. But the bleach mixed with the toilet unblocker still in there causing a chemical reaction and released huge quantities of chlorine gas.  “I have never experienced fumes like it,” Dominique said. “My throat and eyes feel burned.” Dominique quickly shut the bathroom door and opened the windows around the house. However, the chlorine gas began to spread and she sought help from a neighbour and rang the fire brigade, who instantly realised how serious the situation was.The family didn’t get back to bed and sleep until am the following morning. Dominique posted the story on Facebook and shared her embarrassment at having to call out the firefighters, but said she wanted to share her story as a warning to others not to do the same. While the reaction from her friends was one of concern - and a degree of humour - the incident could have been very serious, and many commented that they also had no idea that mixing two normal household materials could effectively create a poisonous gas cloud. “It was really serious,” she said. “We are all ok, but it was the dumbest thing I have ever done - please don’t do this!”

title: parents tell hope tiny tots
story: NewsParents tell of hope for tiny tots born into the UKs leading neonatal unitSPECIAL REPORT: The NHS youngest and smallest patients arrive here and their fate is in the hands of a team of miracle workersShareCommentsByMartyn Halle:,  DEC NewsLittle baby boy Kayden was born  weeks early and is one of the tiny fighters at Southampton Children’s Hospital "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailHis eyes are shut, he is connected to a raft of tubes and wires, but look at his tiny hand… seemingly raised in a gesture of hope. Baby Kayden lies peacefully in the incubator which has been home since his premature arrival into the world last month at just  weeks. Mum Melayne Pragnell is close by, reassured by the wonderful care Kayden is receiving in the state-of-the-art neonatal intensive care unit at Southampton Children’s Hospital. This is where the NHS’s youngest and smallest patients are fighting for their lives – their fate in the hands of medics who perform miracles on a daily basis. Often the tots’ skin is so thin you can see through it. They are clinging on to a le that has only just begun. Last week, the Sunday Mirror was invited to visit the unit as figures show , babies – seven per cent of all UK births – arrive prematurely each year. The atmosphere is calm, professional, yet warm and friendly too. Doctors, nurses and parents talk in hushed tones because noise could hinder recovery.  An illuminated ear on the wall goes from green to amber to red to showthere’s too much noise. It is a peaceful environment of darkened rooms. Incubators are covered by towels so that the still immature eyes of their little occupants aren’t startledthe lights are turned on. Care home worker Melayne, , wasn’t due to have her baby until mid-February. She and partner Kevin McDonough, , had been trying for children for  years and endured three cycles of IVF. But in mid-November Kayden was delivered weighing just g – .lbs – after Melayne developed a shycondition called placenta previa and suffered a potentially le-threatening bleed. Tiny Kayden made good progress, but suddenly declined  days ago after developing a potentially deadly E.coli tummy bug, then sepsis and meningitis. Doctors were on hand to respond quickly and are hopeful he will make a full recovery. Kevin said: “One minute we felt we were on the home straight – he was breathing by himself and things were looking up for Christmas. Then we were faced with a situation where he might be dead by Christmas.  “The doctors were very quick with their antibiotics. They put him to sleep and then put him on a ventilator.” Consultant and mum-of-four Victoria Puddy is one of the best in the field. Since she started  years ago, shyenormous strides have been made. Victoria said: “Now we are saving babies at  weeks when a decade ago we wouldn’t have considered rescuing a child so young. And we are not just saving them, some are leaving here unscathed.” Just five per cent of premature babies are born before  weeks. At  weeks, like Kayden,  per cent survive. Medics at Southampton are also caring for the daughter of a newly-appointed colleague. Abhijit Bhattacharaya, , had been working on the unit for just a week when his we Himakshi, also , went into labour at  weeks. Abhijit said: “I knew things were not good when my boss from neo-natal intensive care came into the theatre. “Our daughter Neysha was not breathing and they took her away and worked on her for  minutes before she started breathing. We are so, so grateful for their expertise.” As Abhijit spoke his we gently cradled Neysha’s hand. And just a few feet away lay another premature baby – tiny Sarah George, born at  weeks to parents Basil, , and Simi, . Doctors are using steroids and oxygen to help her lungs develop. The -cot unit is a centre of expertise when it comes to paediatric heart and neuro surgery. Consultants will even operate on the tots in their cotthey are too fragile to be moved. Like NHS staff nationwide, the team here is dedicated to its work. And that gives the likesof Kayden, Neysha and Sarah the very best ofchances.Find out how you can support the work of Southampton’s Children’s Hospital by visiting schcharity.org.uk

title: saira khan food bosses should
story: NewsopinionSaira Khan: Food bosses should cap calories to save us from ourselvesStealthy food industry tactics have led to obese sugar addicts - and its not just a case of iniduals having more self-discipleShareCommentsBySaira Khan:,  DEC NewsopinionLosing weight is not just about personal discipline, it is also about those in the food industry "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailFor weeks I have used Christmas as an excuse to stuff my face and drink copious amounts of Prosecco. The only exercise I have managed to do is hoist my legs off the floor and on to the sofa.The only weights I have managed to lt is that of the remote control. And the crisp bowl. My Dancing on Ice training took an especially big hit on Christmas Day – I am definitely one of those people who consumed a staggering average of , calories on the th, according to research. And I don’t get where that figure comes from – how can some turkey, a bit of booze and a few chocolates and Christmas pud add up to that  And that’s the problem, isn’t it  Obesity – and the strain our unhealthy lestyles put on the NHS – is on the rise.But while most of us know the dference between healthy and junk food, when it comes to knowing the calories in food, we are literally stuffed. And it’s the hidden calories manufacturers sneak in that bug me the most. I consider myself a smart and informed person who is totally aware and fully responsible for the choices I make in my le.I understand that, in order for me to lose weight, I have to consume fewer calories than I burn, no matter what diet I’m on.And I get that the daily requirements for a healthy woman is to consume , calories per day. But I am not a nutritionist, I am a busy working mum – and quite frankly I just don’t have the time or the inclination to work out how many calories are in the food I eat.And evenI think I’m making a healthy choice, that’s not always necessarily true... and here come the hidden calories, sneaking their way on to my hips.  Losing weight is not just about personal discipline, it is also about those in the food industry – shysupermarkets, pubs, restaurants and even schools – informing the public in a very simple, clear manner exactly how many calories are in their products. So I welcome Public Health England’s recommendation that there should be a calorie cap on ready meals, supermarket sandwiches and restaurant items. Chief nutritionist Dr Alison Tedstone said: “These are early days in the calorie-reduction programme, but the food industry has a responsibility to act.” What this means is they will have to revamp recipes and rethink meal offerings.The recommendations include a cap of cals on ready meals,  on restaurant mains and , on pizzas. It’s about time too. These big manufacturers have to take responsibility. They have a moral obligation to stop adding unnecessary calories in the form of sugar and fat. Why do you need to add sugar to a slice of chicken   Stealthy ways to make our food more palatable has led to sugar addiction, which causes obesity.I’m not buying excuses from manufacturers that these caps are “unrealistic” – that screams they can’t be bothered and don’t want to spend money. In this fight against obesity, everyone has to do their bit – self-discipline can only go so far. Manufacturers have to start putting morals before profits and appreciate they they play an integral part in the nation’s health.

title: victoria derbyshire leaders must learn
story: NewsopinionVictoria Derbyshire: Leaders must learn from Brits with gritVictoria Derbyshire believes political leaders could learn a thing or two from these inspiring people in the year aheadShareCommentsByVictoria Derbyshire:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsopinionAndy Woodward, Chris Unsworth, Gary Clfe and Steve Walters bravely shared their story with Victoria Derbyshire"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOne of the most enduring shyimages of  for me was the leader of the free world walking up the steps to Air Force One with a piece of toilet paper stuck to his shoe. If ever there was a metaphor for the year in politics, President Trump’s ascent that day was it. It could have been any of our shypoliticians, quite frankly. Over the years, I’ve got used to listeners and viewers telling me how disgusted and disappointed they are with our elected leaders, and  gave those voices extra volume.   The debates are nastier, coarser and there’s a casual hatred in some of our discourse – from both voters and politicians. Despite the plea from the Queen in her festive message, I can’t see that getting any better as we approach the year of Brexit. So who should we be looking to give us a bit of hope for the  months ahead  Who will provide some inspiration to restore our faith in human decency  On my daily BBC news show I am regularly reminded what incredible people make up our country. Distance runner Sophie Power competed in one of the world’s toughest races, the km Ultra-Trail Du Mont Blanc – and breast-fed three-month-old son Cormac on the way round. The image of her doing that went global and on my programme she said: “When we become mums our self-identity doesnt change. We shouldn’t have to lose who we were before we were mothers.”   In February football coach and serial abuser of young boys, Barry Bennell, was sentenced to  years in jail for his crimes. Gary Clfe, Chris Unsworth, Steve Walters and Andy Woodward appeared on my programme to tell their horric stories. They could teach any one of us about courage, because that’s what it took for them to come forward after decades to speak out and testy against their abuser. Sophie and those men didn’t give up. Neither does Marie Gentles – the principled, firm, kind head of a pupil referral unit in East London who allowed our cameras into her school. Many of her students have been excluded from mainstream primaries yet she refuses to believe they are “naughty children”, simply that they’ve made poor choices. Marie and her staff give them another chance – and in most cases, help them turn their lives around. Maybe Theresa May, Jeremy Corbyn, Nicola Sturgeon, Vince Cable and other political leaders could learn from the inspiring people I’ve met this year – having courage, never giving up, showing compassion, and doing what’s right and just.

title: vital 24 hour helpline military
story: Sunderland "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA le-saving helpline for veterans battling with PTSD may have to axe its -hour operation because of a cash crisis. Combat Stress says its round-the-clock service desperately needs funds. Last year it handled more than , calls – up  per cent in a year. But in March the NHS cut shypound.million of Combat Stress’s overall funding – a fth of its income. The charity has already reduced its vital residential care programmes. And now bosses have appealed through the Sunday People for public donations to keep its helpline available at all times.   They chose us because of our Save Our Soldiers campaign, which calls for a radical overhaul of how the Government and military top brass handle post-traumatic stress. Carol Smith, Combat Stress director of client services, said: “We absolutely do not want to reduce the hours.“Our helpline is the first port of call for veterans seeking help and it isreally important they are able to contact us at any time of the day or night.“A lot of calls are made at night because often people with mental health conditions find it dficult to sleep. Many have told us thatthey hadn’t made that call they wouldn’t be here today. “We have enough funding to see us through to April because we have been fortunate enough to receive a couple of legacies. “But after that everything depends on how much money we are able to raise.”  Northern Ireland veteran Chris Batty, who suffers from PTSD, credits the helpline withsaving his le.The former Lance Corporal, from Sunderland, hit rock bottom last December after nearly two decades of self-medicating with alcohol. A former Army pal suggested he contact Combat Stress. Chris, , said: “I had to build up the courage to pick up the phone because it takes a lot to admit you need help.“It was in the middle of the night that I finally made the call and when I came off the phone it felt like someone had turned a valve in me and released a load of pressure. That call was the turning point in my le. I was a raving alcoholic and had lost all hope. I couldn’t see any further.”He started one-to-one sessions with a community psychiatric nurse and took part in the charity’s occupational therapy workshops.In May he was offered a place on Combat Stress’s six-week intensive trauma programme and he nowvolunteers for the charity Veterans in Crisis Sunderland.Chris, who served seven years with the st Battalion, the Light Infantry, in the s, said: “That helpline is a lesaver – I’m the proof of that. It needs to be  . Crises don’t happen between  and , they happen when the veteran is lying in bed at night and can’t sleep or is having night terrors. “I want other veterans to have the same amazing support as I had.” The helpline – costing pound an hour to run – also supports family members of those who have served in the Forces. The new Combat Stress helpline launched in February to support serving members of the Forces is funded by the Ministry of Defence and is not under threat.The Combat Stress helpline for veterans and their families is   . For serving personnel and their loved ones it is   . To find out how you can support the charity go to combatstress.org.uk.

title: man buys entire family dna
story: NewsMan buys entire family DNA tests for Christmas - and there are some shocking resultsA man has revealed how he almost ruined Christmas for his entire family after buying DNA tests for everyoneShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  DEC Updated:,  DEC NewsA man has revealed how he almost ruined his family Christmas"Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTheres always one family member who turns up at Christmas with a rather bizarre present. From homemade items that didnt quite go to plan, to last minute gts purchased on the way over, we thought wed seen it all. But one man has raised the bar for unusual presents by purchasing DNA testing kits for his entire family - and the bemusing item almost ruined Christmas for everyone. The unnamed son revealed all in a post online, which has had thousands of views.  Taking to Reddit, the man starts his story by revealing that earlier in the year AncestryDNA had a sale on their kit and for some reason he thought it would be a great gt, so he bought six of them - one for himself, his mum, his dad, brother and two sisters. However when it came time to open presents on December , the kits didnt exactly garner the reaction hed been hoping for. He wrote: As soon as everyone opened their gt, my mom started freaking out. She told us she didnt want us taking them because they had unsafe chemicals. We explained to her how there were actually no chemicals, but we could tell she was still flustered. Later she started trying to convince us that only one of us kids need to take it since we will all have the same results and to resell extra kits to save money.  The children were still keen to give the tests a go which caused an argument to break out between the parents. According to the post, the pair went upstairs and argued for about an hour, leaving the four kids to wonder what exactly was going on. At this point, the man truly thought hed f***** up and ruined the family Christmas. But then things took a surprising turn.  His parents eventually came back down and shared some shocking news with them all - one of them had a dferent dad. He explained: Turns out my sisters father passed away shortly after she was born. A good friend of my moms was able to help her through the darkest time in her le, and they went on to fall in love and create the rest of our family. They never told us because of how hard it was for my mom. The parents went on to share stories and photos for the first time and the son claims the experience brought them even closer together as a family.  He added: This is a Christmas we will never forget. And yes, we are all excited to get out test results. Merry Christmas everyone! More than , people have taken the time to comment on his post, with many sharing their own unusual family stories. One person wrote: I was adopted by my grandparents and didnt know until I was older. The person I grew up with as an older sister was actually my biological mother. Another said: My friend discovered through AncestryDNA that her grandpa wasnt actually her grandpa. Her actual grandpa was one of her grandparents neighbours. A third added: I work at AncestryDNA. This actually happens all the time.
